title: Naming Each Page in a React Application
excerpt: Learn how to set a unique title for each page in your React application using document.title and best practices.
content:
In a React application, setting a unique title for each page is essential to improve user experience and search engine optimization (SEO). This guide explains how to dynamically name each page using document.title.

1. Define the Title in Each Component

Add a line in the React component of each page to update the document's title:

document.title = 'Home - SportSee';

Here is an example for a home page:

const Home = () => {
  document.title = 'Home - SportSee';
  return (
    <div className="home">home</div>
  );
};

2. Avoid Naming Each Page Manually

To avoid naming each page individually, you can use a centralized approach. This allows you to manage all titles in one file, simplifying maintenance and reducing potential errors.

const pageTitles = {
  home: 'Home - SportSee',
  about: 'About Us - SportSee',
  dashboard: 'Dashboard - SportSee'
};

Then, import these titles into each page and update the title dynamically:

document.title = pageTitles.home;

3. Use a Custom Hook

To further simplify title management, you can create a custom Hook:

import { useEffect } from 'react';

const useDocumentTitle = (title) => {
  useEffect(() => {
    document.title = title;
  }, [title]);
};

Example of usage:

const Home = () => {
  useDocumentTitle('Home - SportSee');
  return (
    <div className="home">home</div>
  );
};

Conclusion

By defining unique titles for each page of your React application, you not only improve user experience but also enhance your site's SEO. Adopt a centralized approach or use Hooks for simplified management.
